thread.title: Editorial: Flyover feedback: Public safety over concrete

author: DispatchDaemon
title: Editorial: Flyover feedback: Public safety over concrete
text:
In November 1968, the Interstate 16 flyover into downtown Savannah opened to traffic for the first time, heralded as the latest and greatest addition to the relatively new American interstate system.
However, the economic toll the flyover took on the Martin Luther King Jr., corridor, back then called West Broad Street and to black-owned businesses in the area was disproportionate to any other neighborhood.
Whereas the neighborhood had once been home to two local theaters, doctors’ offices, restaurants and bars, after the highway came in people moved out and many businesses shut down or were razed.
One of the areas most affected by the flyover was a once-thriving neighborhood called Frogtown, which dates back to the American Revolution and was settled by freed slaves after the Civil War.
By the 1970s, many of its residents had moved away and the city’s health department condemned more than a dozen homes that had fallen into disrepair, effectively emptying the area of inhabitants.
Union Station, an architecturally stunning structure razed by the city in the early ’60s, ahead of the highway, also used to stand there. Its demolition was an architectural tragedy.
If the ramp is removed, say planners, about 5 acres of public land could be reclaimed and another 12.5 acres of vacant or under-used private land could be re-developed as well.
Funding for the removal, which was included in the defeated 2012 transportation sales tax referendum, has not yet been identified, but the project has been included in local and state long-range plans in anticipation of receiving federal funds.
The proposal to remove the flyover, reroute traffic and open MLK to more revitalization has been on the table for a long time. As the saying goes, it’s time to fish or cut bait.
Local residents will get their chance to provide planners their feedback today when the Metropolitan Planning Commission holds a Reclaiming Old West Broad Street meeting from 5-7 p.m. at the Savannah Civic Center. Planners want to showcase proposals for tearing down the Interstate 16 flyover ramp leading into downtown, and they want public input on the project.
“Essentially, we have two concepts, and each concept has two alternatives,” said Tom Thomson, executive director of the MPC.
Both concepts include new ramps to U.S. 17 at West Oglethorpe Avenue, which connects with I-16. These new ramps would allow drivers to both enter and exit the highway system at Oglethorpe Avenue from U.S. 17 northbound and southbound — current access is limited to an exit from U.S. 17 southbound or entrance to U.S. 17 northbound.
Here are two realities: Whatever option is pursued it won’t come cheaply. Or quickly. Estimated costs run from $67.3 million to $70.3 million depending on which option is selected.
Construction is far off, but what planners need to do now is get approval on a plan and begin the process of a deeper environmental-impact analysis, which makes good sense.
“My guess is before there’s a development-ready block, we’re probably talking seven to 10 years,” Thomson said.
Plans are to return Montgomery Street to a two-way street after the ramp’s removal.
“Really, what this means is downtown development will move west,” Thomson said.
Today’s meeting will provide residents an opportunity to offer their feedback and see for themselves if the removal of the Interstate 16 flyover is worth $70 million.
And don’t forget studying the possibility of saving the flyover and turning it into an overhead park, which has been done in other cities. A group of local citizens supports that option to convert it to a “High Line” park.
The goal of correcting gross mistakes made decades ago is worth supporting. But leaders should be guided by several rules as they study the options:
• Don’t make matters worse when it comes to traffic safety and flow. The current flyover is getting the job done by providing eastbound motorists an easy and efficient way to get downtown. Forcing motorists to use a less efficient, more complicated downtown road grid may not be a fair trade-off.Any proposal that boosts traffic congestion in that major gateway to Savannah should be shot down.
• Make the area more pedestrian friendly. Pedestrians now take their lives into their own hands, or their own feet, when they attempt to cross MLK on foot. Any flyover improvement must also keep pedestrians in mind, especially if revitalization is the ultimate goal.
• The biggest impediment to revitalization in that area or most areas in the inner city is crime. Those who believe that tearing down the flyover will automatically result in prosperity for neighborhoods south of the flyover are fooling themselves. Investing millions in public safety may be a smarter investment than investing millions in concrete.
